question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
Let \emph{u} be a unit vector and \emph{Q = I - 2uu\textsuperscript{T}}.
Show:

\textbf{(b)} The matrix \emph{Q + iI} is invertible.
sols:
Recall the definition of the eigenvalue, we know that $-i$ is one of
Q$^{\prime}$s eigenvalues when $det(Q+iI)=0$, and $Q+iI$ is invertible
if and only if $det(Q+iI)\neq 0$. From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2008/Question_06_(a)}{part
a}, we know that Q is a symmetric matrix. A symmetric matrix will only
have real eigenvalues and since $-i$ is not real, it is not an
eigenvalue of Q and $det(Q+iI)$ is never equal to zero.

Therefore, the matrix $Q+iI$ is invertible.
